All know what noise was occasioned by the action of Clodius, who put on women's apparel, that he might be present with the Roman ladies at the feast of the good goddess. Yet others think that Moses here forbids some superstitious practices.

No... it *still is* a moral code. And it's still necessary to follow the Mosaic Law to fulfill the mission that Jesus put out [Matthew 5:17-20] and is sustained through the teachings of Peter, John, **James**, and the author of Hebrews. No... it *still is* a moral code. And it's still necessary to follow the Mosaic Law to fulfill the mission that Jesus put out [Matthew 5:17-20] and is sustained through the teachings of Peter, John, **James**, and the author of Hebrews. [whereas the Pauline epistles, and the Pauline message, are going out to people not of the Jewish "holy (set apart)" race — although Jews could still believe in Paul's message, if they felt the calling of pure grace]

> Morality and holiness aren't something that can be decoupled, though.

Yes, they can. In fact, they must be, or we end up making claims like "putting on a dress as a male is immoral, as a universal moral principle", which will be greatly shamed at the Great White Throne judgement.

> You could say one is a subcategory of the other

This is the truth. There are many things in the Mosaic code which *are* universal moral principles, but there are others which are obviously not. "Where we draw the line" could be a problem, which is why the entire problem is sidestepped in the Pauline evangel by *insisting* that we are *not under law*, but under **grace!**

One must read Romans and understand that they are not to undermine the extraordinary spiritual truths therein by trying to jam the message that the Gospel accounts teach [a message that Jesus explicitly made sure did not go outside the land of Israel, Matthew 10:5-6], that James teaches [by the way, James 1:1 explicitly says that the message is for Israelites!], that Peter teaches, and that Hebrews, [named such because of the Jewish message therein] and instead understanding Paul as the only man who was given the universal principles of 'the grace of God and the gratuity in grace, which ... superabounds'

And as it is only the body of Christ that is to be raptured away prior to the tribulation, and the bride of the Lamb to overcome through it, this acclaiming of the Pauline message is a Noah's Ark situation: either you will get on, or you will experience the consequences of being on the earth during Jacob's trouble.
